name: Roy Walker
description:
Roy Walker is a PhD student of Dr Patrick Cai and Prof. Alistair Elfick. Roy’s PhD project focuses on designing, assembling and characterising a tRNA neochromosome as part of the Sc2.0 consortium. Roy’s research interests otherwise focus on the biotechnology and molecular biology of the model yeast, Saccharomyces cerevisiae.
Roy received a bachelor’s degree with honours in biochemistry from Heriot-Watt University, Edinburgh, followed by one year of experience in industry with Lallemand Inc. (Montreal, Canada). Past research experience also includes work at the Translational Medicine Research Collaboration (Dundee, Scotland), DSM Nutritional Products (Kaiseraugst, Switzerland) and further work with Lallemand Inc. at the University of Abertay (Dundee, Scotland). 
In his spare time, Roy enjoys photography, travelling, brewing beer, practicing Taekwondo, and playing the guitar.

name: Olivia Wei Liu
description: Wei is a PhD student in her final year in Cai Lab. She got her bachelor's degree in Biological Science from Ocean University of China and joint the lab in 2013 for her PhD study with Patrick. She entered the field of synthetic biology by participating in the iGEM competition. She was the leader of 2011 OUC iGEM team and supervised the 2012 OUC iGEM team. Her PhD research projects include developing tyrosine recombinase in vivo for orthogonal SCRaMbLE of synthetic chromosomes for the Sc2.0 consortium and in vitro recombinase toolkit for metabolic engineering. She’s also working on the synthetic natural product (SynNP) project to discover new antibiotics using the synthetic biology platform. She likes travelling, seafood, Ceilidh, concert and music shows. She loves pipette but is also learning to play violin and ukulele to enjoy life.

name: Paulina Kanigowska
description: Paulina is a PhD student from Poland. Her main interest and scientific focus is laboratory automation and its application in the synthetic biology domain. In the Cai Lab, she works on establishing high-throughput DNA manufacturing and editing protocols, as well as investigates the biological workflows from a process engineering perspective, to better understand and address their limitations. Prior to the postgraduate studies, Paulina obtained a bachelor’s degree in Biotechnology from the University of Edinburgh.

name: Chantal Yue Shen
description: Chantal Yue Shen is currently a PhD student of Dr. Patrick Cai and Dr. Chris French. She received a bachelor degree of Bioengineering from South China University of Technology (China) and a master degree of Biomedical Engineering from The University of Melbourne (Australia). Chantal has earned four years experiences involving bioinformatics, molecular biology as well as project management in BGI-Shenzhen. Her research interests are combing Bioinformatics, Engineering and Molecular Biology for exploring potential applications of Synthetic Biology. Chantal is now focusing on the Sc2.0 project and the development of DNA synthesis and assembly platform with automation of technologies.

name: Jamie Auxillos
description:
Jamie is a PhD student at the Cai lab under the supervision of Dr. Patrick Cai and Professor Chris French. She graduated with a BSc Hons in Biomedical Sciences with Medical Microbiology in 2014 at Newcastle University and an MSc in Systems and Synthetic Biology at the University of Edinburgh in 2015. 
Her project focusses on the application of synthetic biology and high-throughput biology in drug discovery, specifically antibiotics against tuberculosis. This project is in collaboration with researchers at the Tyres lab (University of Montreal) and the Wright lab (McMaster University). Her interests lie in the application of synthetic biology in the development of treatments and therapies against diseases.

title: Dr.
name: Andrea Martella
description:
My research project is focused on development of new tools and strategies that facilitate the design and production of mammalian expression vectors and megabase-size DNA constructs. 
My current project is in collaboration with Dr. Steve Pollard’s lab at the MRC Centre for Regenerative Medicine (CRM), a research centre based at the University of Edinburgh. I developed the EMMA toolkit that will be used to accelerate the discovery of new drugs for treatment of glioblastoma and to test new hypotheses in the field of regenerative medicine. 
I obtained my doctorate degree in 2014 at the Erasmus Medical Center, Cell Biology department, Rotterdam, The Netherland. Under the supervision of Prof. Frank Grosveld, my research project was focused on transcription factors and signalling pathways involved in differentiation of mesodermal precursors towards hematopoietic and endothelial lineages.

name: Aileen Greig
description:
Aileen. Married. Mother of 4. Loves cats and dogs. Enjoys a laugh. 
Aileen has worked at Edinburgh University in a technical capacity for 26 years and was part of the ICMB within Prof Adrian Bird's lab until 2009, before becoming a member of Prof Mike Tyers' lab for 5 years. Aileen now supports the Cai lab in most technical disciplines.

title: Dr.
name: Dariusz Abramczyk
description:
My scientific interest lies in the field of fungal molecular biology and microbiology. I graduated with MSc in Biotechnology and PhD in Molecular Biology from Maria Curie-Sklodowska University in Poland. Following postdoctoral training at the University of Texas at Austin and University of Manchester, I joined University of Edinburgh working on short-term projects including the regulation of ribosome biosynthesis in yeast and, subsequently, an industrial project applying the engineering of metabolic pathways in bacteria for production of fungal polysaccharides. Currently, I am a researcher in Dr. Patrick Cai group working on projects related to the synthetic yeast genome project (Sc2.0). 
My main research goals:
Creating strains with multiple synthetic chromosomes in one cell
Phenotypic study of yeast synthetic strains
To establish a SCRaMbLE protocol for cell batch transfer to evaluate independent strain evolution and generate synthetic yeast strains with valuable phenotypes for growth, such as high ethanol concentration and glucose-limiting conditions.

name: Emily Scher
description: Emily is a PhD Student in the Cai Lab. She graduated in 2014 with a BSc in Computer Science from John's Hopkins University. She has had internships at several software companies including Google and Cisco, and before her PhD was working as a Software Development Engineer at Amazon.

name: Katarina Jonsson
description: Katarina graduated from the University of Edinburgh in June 2015 with a BSc (Hons) in Molecular Biology. She is continuing her studies here in Edinburgh as a PhD student in the Cai and Marston labs where she is synthesising mini-yeast chromosomes and testing their ability to segregate during mitosis. During Katarina’s spare time she likes to read, hike and go to the cinema.
